author: @mimosveta
text: lol I was just talking to some canadian about that property thing. well, he said that canada is communist, so, that too, but when he said he likes private property I told him pretty much the same thing as noah here >< you have the right to private property, and you rent, and in communist yugoslavia, we had no right to private property, but we all had homes and cars, and other forms of "personal" property. most people already don't own toothbrush factories so, like, yeah

author: @dcorgard
text: I see Private Property = Profiting Property or Rent-seeking Property. Some investment firm shouldn't be able to buy up half the housing of a community, outbidding everyone else with cash, then artificially inflating the rent on the houses so regular people can't ever own then. That's how I understand the eradication of Private Property - not the confiscation of Personal property, but barring Capital from grabbing up all the land solely for profit.

text:
Does Noah read these comments?

His explanation of why "classless moneyless stateless society" is not a phraseology that is ever emphasised by Marx was actually really good and I think he should have finished it instead of handing the mic over to Carlos. Does he ever go into this argument in detail in another video? If not will he give it a go in his next show?

author: @Arnaere
text: Look Kiko's Freethinker asked a really good question: how do you make the terminology immediately appealing. The philosophical diatribe did not cut to the core of the problem. Hopefully this video gets reviewed and we find ways to exert influential ways of applying quick and impactful language to the, forgive me, marketability of the language.

author: @dougsjourney9961
text: Do Engels and Bukarin state that communism is a classless stateless society? It’s my understanding that Marx doesn’t say it explicitly, but what about them? And how do you guys feel about how they describe it?

replies.author: @khrachvikkhrachvik7049
replies.text:
They don’t, no. I genuinely hate that shorthand, even though I understand why people developed it. 

The problem isn’t the phrase itself, but how we think about it in modern bourgeois society. Marx tells us that Communism is the Real movement of history. And when we use this shorthand, we lose sight of that and instead tend to reduce ourselves to Utopianism, which is what Marx and Engels began their work in order to overcome. 

The theory of the withering of the state only makes sense if we do not imagine a future society that we will into existence.

replies.author: @dougsjourney9961
replies.text:
@ I get that. My experience with normal Americans (mis)understanding and (mis)identification of communism usually consists of them having the following understanding:

1. Authoritarianism + everyone equal outcome

2. Classless, Stateless utopian society.

Getting people past these elementary understandings is definitely one of the first hurdles for getting people to open their minds to communism / Marxist-Leninism. I think once people get past that, then they can open their mind to having a better understanding of it and see the benefit in being a part of this movement of history instead of trying to fight it. (Let me know If that’s a sound understanding of the role of the working class or if I’m slightly off….I’m still learning)

I mean, he clearly states that THE STATE is a creation of the means of production being PRIVATE and it is the instrument of coercion used by the particular ruling class of an epoch. WTF are you talking about??

author: @New_soul9
text: I have a question. Do u guys believe a direct democracy can work? Rather than a representative

replies.author: @BcroG11
replies.text: You can have a combination of the two. For example, do a referendum on every issue that is not decided by an at least 60 % majority in the Parliament.

replies.author: @New_soul9
replies.text: @BcroG11   Gotcha. Out of those 60% it can only be those who are educated of set issues, and the one that aren't their vote wouldn't be valid?

replies.author: @BcroG11
replies.text: @New_soul9 I wouldn't overcomplicate it. I'd have a parliamentary democracy like it is now (without the moneyed influences, ofc). Formal education does not guarantee good decision-making, anyway.

replies.author: @New_soul9
replies.text: @BcroG11  wait can u elaborate? I didn't understand your comment 😅can u brake it down more easily?

replies.author: @ranovich6734
replies.text:
​@Newsoul9 He's explaining the need to have represented officials essentially be working people and from the working class, and the fact that education (in any political topic) doesn't assure 'correct- or 'educated' decision making.. It should ultimately have the involvement of the masses.

This is talked about extensively in a lot of Marx's works, also in works like State and Revolution by Lenin, who argues the issues of professional bureaucrats and red-tapism.

Feel free to ask more

Appreciated 👍🏽💯

author: @jorgeclaverie6752
text: PLEASE stop offending the peoples of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay, Colombia, Cuba, Mexico, Venezuela, Canada, Perú, Uruguay, etc. by using the name of their CONTINENT to refer only to USA. PLEASE study a little History and Geography and you will see that "America" is NOT the name of one single country but that of a huge and diverse continent. Columbus came to America on FOUR occasions and NEVER ever set foot on what is now US territory. Let me reiterate this: Columbus came to America FOUR TIMES and was not ever in what is now USA. Then, the Europeans called this place where he had been "America". Now..., what does this tell you about the real meaning of the name "America"???!!!! 🙂  Please, guys, it is high time you gave your country a proper name already!!! It is not anyone else´s fault if YOU have decided to call your federation "The United States of a CONTINENT”, is it? Consider this: if France had decided to call itself "United Provinces of Europe", would you then only call France "Europe"? How do you think the people in the rest of Europe would react?

replies.author: @khrachvikkhrachvik7049
replies.text: No.

replies.author: @khrachvikkhrachvik7049
replies.text:
Okay. Sorry, that “no” was a joke. 

I think we run into a few problems here. That’s all. 

1. The country is called the “United states of America” and as such, the word we’ve ALWAYS used is Americans. It in no way says “other people on this continent are not American” and I don’t understand where you get that idea from? It’s simply referring to the specific people of the USA.

2. In Spanish, there’s actually a word for it. And it makes sense and comes naturally when speaking Spanish, so obviously that’s  what we do

3. Liberals and anti-communists have for too long tried to force people to virtue signal, you know? Say the right magic words or you’re in trouble! And it’s always some unnatural way of speaking they demand we all change, when the way we were already speaking worked just fine and the proper notions were already being communicated. 

4. Using the correct woke word doesn’t actually change anything. If you believe we’re somehow disrespecting our brothers and sisters in other countries while we’re actively working with them on our shared interests and for material gains, I don’t know what to tell ya, my friend. I would suggest checking out @ACPmain on Twitter/X and you’ll see that you are just sort of… repeating a line that liberals believe is true but does not properly reflect the reality. 

5. Focus on language and not content, the real essence of things, is just not the way Communists roll. That’s all. 

I hope you take this in the good-hearted way I mean it. Too often, these problems get exacerbated for no good reason, you know? Really, I’m just saying… we need to genuinely think about this kind of thing.
